results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) = C(n,k) + 3*C(n,k+1) + 2*C(n,k+2) (0<=k<=n).
comment: Binomial transform of the infinite tridiagonal matrix M with main diagonal (1,1,1...), subdiagonal (3,3,3...) and subsubdiagonal (2,2,2...).
Sum of entries in row n = 6*2^n-2n-5 = A050488(n+1).
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n=0..100 of triangle, flattened
formula: exp(x) * e.g.f. for row n = e.g.f. for diagonal n. For example, for n = 3 we have exp(x)*(16 + 14*x + 6*x^2/2! + x^3/3!) = 16 + 30*x + 50*x^2/2! + 77*x^3/3! + 112*x^4/4! + .... The same property holds more generally for Riordan arrays of the form ( f(x), x/(1 - x) ). Cf. A233295. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 21 2014
maple: T:=(n,k)->binomial(n,k)+3*binomial(n,k+1)+2*binomial(n,k+2): for n from 0 to 11 do seq(T(n,k),k=0..n) od; # yields sequence in triangular form
program: (PARI) for(n=0,15, for(k=0,n, print1(binomial(n,k) + 3*binomial(n,k+1) + 2*binomial(n,k+2), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Oct 23 2018
